user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_remove:
```c
int lfs_remove(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_remove(%p, \"%s\")", (void*)lfs, path);

    err = lfs_remove_(lfs, path);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_remove -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_remove:
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I did not include other fragments because they do not present non-const pointer declarations that could be readily qualified as const from the shown code: - cfg is already declared as const (const struct lfs_config *cfg). - path is already const-qualified in the function parameter (const char *path). - rcache, pcache, root, seed, gstate, gdisk, gdelta, block_count, name_max, file_max, attr_max, inline_max are not pointer declarations in the provided excerpts. - The LFS_LOCK/LFS_UNLOCK and LFS_TRACE macro calls only use existing pointers (cfg, lfs, path) but do not declare pointer types; cfg/path are already appropriately const-qualified. - The call site err = lfs_remove_(lfs, path); is a function invocation (not a pointer type declaration) and any needed const-qualification should be checked in the callee's prototype/definition (not visible here). - No other pointer member declarations are present in the shown struct definitions. Therefore only the listed non-const pointer declarations should be investigated for possible const-qualification.
